channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: Indonesia Tsunami Toll Soars Amid Push to Save Survivors
item.media:description: Debris from a collapsed hotel was scattered on Sunday in Palu, on the Indonesian island of Sulawesi.
item.description: The confirmed death toll has passed 800, officials said, but that is expected to rise significantly as rescuers scramble to reach the worst-hit areas.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Hit Men and Power: South Africa’s Leaders Are Killing One Another
item.media:description: Incomplete and dilapidated housing near Umzimkhulu, South Africa. A whistle-blower who condemned corruption in the area is now in hiding.
item.description: About 90 politicians have been killed in South Africa since 2016. And in most cases, African National Congress officials are killing one another.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI and SELAM GEBREKIDAN

item.title: Senegal Dispatch: Across Senegal, the Beloved Baobab Tree Is the ‘Pride of the Neighborhood’
item.media:description: Selbe Dione and her sister harvesting baobab leaves to cook with couscous in the countryside of western Senegal.
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.description: Baobabs have endured for centuries as essential cultural symbols. But increasingly, they are threatened by climate change, urbanization and a growing population.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: On Crowded London Streets, Councils Fight a Flood of Phone Boxes
item.media:description: London is being flooded with new phone boxes. Critics say they are basically glorified billboards, but planning laws treat them as an essential utility.
item.media:credit: Jane Stockdale for The New York Times
item.description: Proposals for hundreds of public phones plastered with ads have set off a battle over Britain’s public space.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN MUELLER

item.title: Turkey Clamps Down on a Group Erdogan Once Championed: Grieving Mothers
item.media:description: Turkish riot police grabbing members of the Saturday Mothers group last month at one of its weekly protests in Istanbul.
item.description: A group of mothers held weekly vigils for missing sons for years, and Recep Tayyip Erdogan once vowed to help. But the government recently banned the rallies, a sign, critics said, of rising authoritarianism.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: From Hero to Pariah, Aung San Suu Kyi Dashes Hopes About Myanmar
item.media:description: “Rarely has the reputation of a leader fallen so far, so fast,” the International Crisis Group said of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi.
item.description: Myanmar’s civilian leader, once a democracy icon, has become known as an enabler for the ethnic cleansing of Rohingya Muslims and a foe of the free press.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: A Social Media Star Is Shot Dead in Baghdad. Iraqis Fear a Trend.
item.media:description: The killing of Tara Fares has raised fears of a coordinated campaign to silence outspoken women in Iraq.
item.description: Tara Fares was gunned down in broad daylight, the latest outspoken woman killed in a series of attacks that Iraqi officials are investigating as possibly linked.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: ‘No Way’ North Korea Will Denuclearize Without U.S. Concessions
item.media:description: The North Korean foreign minister, Ri Yong-ho, said his country had “reasons to distrust” the United States. He spoke at the United Nations General Assembly on Saturday.
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.description: North Korea’s foreign minister demanded American action first, while President Trump said he and Kim Jong-un, the North’s leader, “fell in love.”
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: A Prostitute Was Killed in France. Is a New Law Partly to Blame?
item.media:description: People gathered to pay tribute to Vanesa Campos, a 36-year-old transsexual prostitute who was killed in Paris in August.
item.description: French lawmakers passed a measure two years ago they said would make life safer for prostitutes. Some say it has put them in a lot more danger.
item.dc:creator: ELIAN PELTIER and EMMA BUBOLA

item.title: U.S. Weighed Penalizing El Salvador Over Support for China, Then Backed Off
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Carlos Castaneda of El Salvador, left, and his Chinese counterpart, Wang Yi, at a ceremony in Beijing last month to establish diplomatic ties between their countries.
item.description: The White House wanted to cut aid to El Salvador after it severed diplomatic ties with Taiwan in favor of China. But that could have jeopardized efforts to curb illegal immigration.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Pope Defrocks Fernando Karadima, Priest at Center of Abuse Outrage in Chile
item.media:description: Fernando Karadima, once a revered priest, being escorted from the Supreme Court building in Santiago, Chile, in 2015.
item.description: Francis once defended a bishop accused of covering up the case, prompting a storm of protest, but an about-face has led to a widespread reckoning in the country.
item.dc:creator: PASCALE BONNEFOY

item.title: Catalan Separatists Clash With Police in Barcelona
item.media:description: Supporters of Catalonian independence sprayed colored powder during a clash with police officers Saturday in Barcelona.
item.description: Catalan separatists clashed with police in Barcelona as tensions heighten ahead of the anniversary of the region’s referendum on secession.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: China’s Leaders Confront an Unlikely Foe: Ardent Young Communists
item.media:description: Activists in Shenzhen last month protested in support of workers’ rights. Their banners call for the punishment of corrupt police officials and the release of detained factory workers.
item.description: The Chinese Communist Party is cracking down on a group of student protesters who have done little but fight for communism’s values and praise Marx, Mao and President Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: In Erdogan’s Charm Offensive, Germans Find Offense
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany in Berlin on Friday.
item.description: A three-day state visit by the Turkish president was supposed to help repair relations. It has fallen short.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Indonesia Tsunami and Quake Devastate an Island, Killing Hundreds
item.media:description: Patients and medical personnel outside a hospital in Palu on Saturday.
item.description: On Sunday, a spokesman for the Indonesian disaster agency said the toll from the twin disasters had doubled, to at least 832 people.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BEECH, MUKTITA SUHARTONO and RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Deadly Earthquake and Tsunami Hit Indonesia
item.description: On Sunday, the death toll from a 7.5-magnitude earthquake and tsunami on the island of Sulawesi, Indonesia, had doubled, to 832 people.

item.title: UNDERSTANDING THE TIMES: 3 Times Journalists on How They Cover Others’ Hometowns in an Era of Twitter Storms
item.description: “The people we’re writing about read our pieces instantaneously, look for inaccuracies and tell us we’re full of baloney. This is not glamorous,” writes Ellen Barry, a Times correspondent based in London. “But it is basically a good thing. It makes us better.”
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Bill Blair on the Firing Line: The Canada Letter
item.media:description: A woman holding a handgun and her target at an indoor shooting range in Port Coquitlam, British Columbia.
item.description: Cabinet minister Bill Blair is starting likely contentious public meetings as he looks into a possible ban on handguns and assault rifles in Canada.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Blaming Iran, U.S. Evacuates Consulate in Southern Iraq
item.media:description: An Iraqi protester stands outside of the Iranian consulate on Sept. 7 in Basra, Iraq. Some demonstrators protesting Iran’s influence in Iraq had set it on fire.
item.description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said the employees were being temporarily relocated and the United States would respond to attacks by militias supported by Iran.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Yemen War Investigation Is Extended by U.N. Council
item.media:description: A Yemeni woman holding a malnourished child awaiting treatment at a hospital in Al Hudaydah.
item.description: An expert panel will continue to look into whether a Saudi-led coalition is guilty of war crimes in the world’s poorest country.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Brett Kavanaugh, Jeff Flake, Tesla: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JOUMANA KHATIB, BLAKE WILSON and HIROKO MASUIKE

item.title: Netherlands, Saying It Foiled a Major Terrorist Attack, Arrests 7
item.media:description: Police officers outside an apartment in Rotterdam on Thursday, as part of a coordinated operation against what the authorities said was a terrorist cell planning a multisite attack in the Netherlands.
item.description: A police operation across several towns and cities yielded powerful guns and bomb-making materials.
item.dc:creator: MILAN SCHREUER

item.title: Seven Palestinians Killed in Gaza Border Clash
item.media:description: Palestinian protesters reacting to tear gas fired by Israeli soldiers during a protest at Gaza’s border with Israel.
item.description: The dead included two boys who were among thousands of people who thronged to the border as part of weekly protests.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: ‘I Don’t Think People in the U.S. Know How Closely We’re Watching This’
item.media:description: Christine Blasey Ford and Brett M. Kavanaugh testified Thursday before the Senate Judiciary Committee.
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff for The New York Times
item.description: International readers tell us how the testimony of Christine Blasey Ford and Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh before the Senate Judiciary Committee affected their perceptions of the United States.
item.dc:creator: GENEVA ABDUL and LELA MOORE

item.title: Gender Politics 101: Teaching Refugees About Sex and Consent in Sweden
item.description: Refugees who are settling in Sweden are learning how to become members of Swedish society. For many newcomers from the Middle East, that means shifting thinking about sex and relationships.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: In Germany, a Social Democrat Who Welcomes Trump’s Bluster
item.media:description: Olaf Scholz, Germany’s new finance minister, says the Trump administration “has become a catalyst for an ever closer European integration.”
item.description: The country’s new finance minister, Olaf Scholz, says the president’s anti-globalist policies are acting as a catalyst for European integration.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD and JACK EWING

item.title: Canada’s Parliament Moves to Strip Honor for Myanmar’s Leader
item.media:description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi with prime minister Justin Trudeau of Canada in Ottawa last year.
item.description: Canada’s House of Commons voted to revoke the honorary citizenship of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi for not criticizing violence by Myanmar’s military against the Rohingya.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Doubts Mount in Botswana Over Charity’s Claim of Elephant ‘Poaching Frenzy’
item.media:description: Elephants in northern Botswana this month. The charity Elephants Without Borders has been accused of exaggerating the poaching problem to try to influence the country’s government.
item.description: Critics say that Elephants Without Borders made exaggerated claims to try to influence the government, which is considering rolling back a hunting ban.
item.dc:creator: KIMON de GREEF
item.category: Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species

item.title: Pret A Manger Allergy Labeling Ruled ‘Inadequate’ After Teen’s Death
item.media:description: The chief executive of Pret A Manger said it would ensure that “meaningful change” resulted from the death of Natasha Ednan-Laperouse, who had an allergic reaction to unlabeled sesame.
item.description: Natasha Ednan-Laperouse had a severe allergy to sesame. The baguette she picked up at the sandwich chain carried no mention of the seeds baked into its dough.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Tsunami and Earthquake in Indonesia Kill Nearly 400, Officials Say
item.media:description: A damaged mosque in the Indonesian city of Palu on Saturday. Officials said the death toll from an earthquake and tsunami that struck Sulawesi island on Friday night had reached 384 in Palu alone.
item.description: Hundreds were killed in the city of Palu alone, and it was feared that the toll could rise further still.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK and MUKTITA SUHARTONO

item.title: China Censors Bad Economic News Amid Signs of Slower Growth
item.media:description: A market on the outskirts of Harbin, China. Negative economic news could undermine the careful message that Chinese officials have tried to transmit to the public in recent months.
item.description: New directives betray a mounting anxiety among Chinese leaders that the country could be facing a worsening slump as the trade war with the United States intensifies.
item.dc:creator: SUI-LEE WEE and LI YUAN

item.title: 5 Takeaways on President Trump’s Foreign Policy From the U.N. General Assembly
item.media:description: President Trump addressed the United Nations General Assembly in New York.
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: President Trump and American officials clarified their policy in a range of hot spots: North Korea, Syria, Iran, Israel and China. Oh, and Canada.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: In Hong Kong, Hepatitis E Strain Jumps From Rats to Humans
item.media:description: In densely populated areas like Hong Kong, “infections that jump from animals to humans must be taken very seriously,” one researcher said.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: Researchers stressed the seriousness of even one case of animal-to-human infection in densely populated areas.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL VICTOR and TIFFANY MAY

item.title: At War: Afghan War Casualty Report: Sept. 6-27
item.media:description: Afghan security officers inspect the scene of a suicide attack in Kabul, Afghanistan, in September.
item.description: This first entry of the Afghan War casualty report goes back to Sept. 6, when 400 Afghan soldiers and police officers were reportedly killed in one week.

item.title: For Xi Jinping, Being a Man of the People Means Looking the Part
item.media:description: Top: President Xi Jinping with farmers in northeastern China this week. Bottom: A propaganda poster of Mao Zedong in the countryside.
item.media:credit: Xie Huanchi/Xinhua, via Associated Press; Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
item.description: A tour of farms and factories in China’s northeast gave Mr. Xi a chance to look like Mao and take aim at Trump.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Journalist Who Spread Conspiracy Theories Will Oversee Italy’s State TV
item.media:description: The appointment of Marcello Foa as chairman of Italy’s state broadcaster RAI marks a victory of the populist parties over the establishment press that once discounted them.
item.description: The appointment of Marcello Foa has raised alarms and marks a victory of the populist parties over the establishment media that once discounted them.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Their Plane Was Set to Land. The Water Rushed In. Then, the Boats Came.
item.media:description: This Air Niugini plane missed the runway of an airport on the remote island of Weno, in Micronesia, on Friday. All 47 people on board were safely evacuated.
item.description: Residents in small boats rushed to the crash site to save passengers and crew members from the sinking aircraft, an official said.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Israeli-Palestinian Divide Deepens, With No Sign of Compromise at U.N.
item.media:description: Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian Authority president, left, and Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister, at the United Nations on Thursday.
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.description: In their General Assembly speeches, the Palestinian and Israeli leaders offered starkly opposing appraisals of an intractable dispute.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Israeli Leader Claims Iran Has ‘Secret Atomic Warehouse’
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel speaking at the United Nations General Assembly on Thursday in New York.
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.description: Benjamin Netanyahu said intelligence agents had found the facility in Tehran, setting up a challenge to Iran to prove it’s not violating the nuclear deal.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and MEGAN SPECIA
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Abbas Says Trump Administration Has Undermined Two-State Solution
item.description: At the United Nations, President Mahmoud Abbas criticized the Trump administration for what he described as its pro-Israel decisions.

item.title: Kavanaugh Hearings, U.N., Elon Musk: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JOUMANA KHATIB and HIROKO MASUIKE

item.title: ‘Hang the Whites,’ French Rapper Declares. Now He May Face Jail.
item.media:description: A still image from the video of a French rapper, Nick Conrad.
item.description: Few had heard of Nick Conrad, a rapper from a Paris suburb. Then his music video started making the rounds, outraging French lawmakers.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Human Rights Council Ratchets Up Pressure on Myanmar
item.media:description: Rohingya Muslims stranded along the border between Myanmar and Bangladesh in July. Some 750,000 Rohingya were forced to flee to Bangladesh.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: The United Nations body is trying to expedite criminal prosecutions of Myanmar military leaders over a brutal campaign against Rohingya Muslims.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Pompeo Hails Talks With North Korea but Says Sanctions Must Continue
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo at the United Nations Security Council meeting on Thursday.
item.description: The secretary of state said that the world is at “the dawn of a new day” in confronting the North Korean threat, but that pressure must be kept on.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Suspects Are Arrested in Killing of Slovak Journalist and His Fiancée
item.media:description: A memorial for the investigative journalist Jan Kuciak and his fiancée, Martina Kusnirova, in Bratislava, Slovakia.
item.description: Many believe that Jan Kuciak was shot dead because of his work to expose government corruption. Anger at his death eventually forced the prime minister to resign.
item.dc:creator: MIROSLAVA GERMANOVA and MARC SANTORA

item.title: Duterte Says, ‘My Only Sin Is the Extrajudicial Killings’
item.media:description: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines in Manila in August.
item.description: The Philippine president’s statement could bolster the cases against him at the International Criminal Court over a drug war that has left thousands dead.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: China Rejects Trump’s Charges of Meddling in U.S. Elections
item.media:description: President Trump told the United Nations Security Council on Wednesday that the Chinese “do not want me or us to win.”
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: Mr. Trump called a paid China Daily insert in an Iowa newspaper “propaganda.” Chinese officials said the advertising was both lawful and commonplace.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: France’s New Law Against Sexist Catcalls Gets Its First Conviction
item.media:description: A fresco commissioned to reassure female commuters in Lyon, France. The verbal harassment case occurred on a bus in the suburbs of Paris.
item.description: A man was fined for lewd, insulting comments to a woman aboard a bus. He was also jailed, for slapping her behind and hitting the bus driver.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
